name: Nasturtium
climate: Nasturtiums prefer temperate climates that mimic their native habitats.
These plants thrive in climates with mild temperatures and few frosts.
Avoid extremely hot climates, as nasturtiums prefer cooler conditions.
They can also grow in subtropical regions with adequate rainfall.
sunlight: Nasturtiums require full sun to bloom profusely and grow effectively.
Although they prefer full sun, they can tolerate light shade conditions.
Insufficient sunlight may result in fewer flowers and leggy growth.
Ensure at least six hours of direct sunlight for optimal performance.
watering: Water nasturtiums regularly, especially in dry and hot weather conditions.
While they tolerate some drought, consistent moisture ensures lush growth.
Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage is available.
Water thoroughly when the top one inch of soil feels dry to the touch.
soil: Nasturtiums grow best in poor to average, well-drained soils, avoiding rich compost.
Overly fertile soils result in lush foliage at the expense of flowers.
The soil should be well-draining to prevent waterlogged conditions.
They can even tolerate sandy soils, reflecting their native environments.
toxic: Nasturtiums are generally considered non-toxic to both humans and pets.
The flowers and leaves are edible and often used in culinary applications.
extra_care_tip: Deadhead nasturtium flowers frequently to encourage continuous blooming.
They can be susceptible to aphids, so inspect regularly and take action as needed.
